direction.raw_text: Yes. Sports fans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who didn't vote for him. Who probably hate him. Who came out of the womb with guns in their hands.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OVER, THE UNMISTAKABLE SOUND OF PRE-GAME NOISE AT A MAJOR SPORTING EVENT

direction.raw_text: A huge, raucous crowd, almost entirely white and male. Many wearing the Springbok green and gold. Widespread evidence of drinking. Lots of OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS -- the blue, white and orange apartheid flag -- make a defiant statement against the NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS ringing the stadium. On the field, THE RUGBY TEAMS ASSEMBLE and face each other in two lines. The BRITISH LIONS in their white on white with black and red trim, the SPRINGBOKS in their green and gold. Like their supporters, the Springboks are all white, but for one man, who is "colored" (mixed race).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Big, tough, brutal-looking men. Scary. (We may or may not notice Francois Pienaar, standing at the head of the line of Springboks.)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: JASON AND ALL THE OTHER BODYGUARDS

direction.raw_text: At the entrance of the tunnel onto the field, LOTS OF COPS in blue South African Police uniforms. Behind the line of cops, in the tunnel, we find JASON AND ALL THE OTHER BODYGUARDS but for Linga. They are keyed-up, intense -- none more so than Jason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting against the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want your eyes on the crowd at all times. We're staying in the middle of the field. He's going to walk out, shake hands, walk back. Nothing else. Got it? They nod. They are like the players at game time, only the stakes are much higher. Jason looks deeper into the tunnel, straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here we go. Mandela strides down the tunnel towards them, wearing a dark suit. Big crowds energize him. His eyes are alive with excitement. One pace behind him, like a huge, dark shadow, comes Linga. Mandela gives Jason a look, Jason nods. We follow Mandela and the bodyguards out of the tunnel -- EXT. LOFTUS VERSFELD STADIUM - DAY -- onto the field, towards the waiting teams. The crowd rise to their feet. Lots of them jeer Mandela, lots cheer. All the old South African flags are waved at him defiantly -- plus some new ones. Mandela waves to them all, smiling proudly. To him, a crowd is an opportunity to make new friends. But he stays in the center of the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jason and crew are hyper-alert, a human fence around Mandela. Mandela reaches the rugby players. Waiting for him at the head of the Springbok line, wearing the NUMBER 6 JERSEY and captain's armband, is FRANCOIS PIENAAR. Now we know what he does. Mandela extends his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck, captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir. Mandela shakes hands down the line of Springboks, then returns, shaking hands with the British Lions. Quick, perfunctory handshakes. As Mandela does this, we take BODYGUARD POV SNAPSHOTS of the crowd, increasingly keyed-up and restless. Time to play rugby. Mandela finishes, waves to the crowd, and begins the walk along the center of the field, back to the tunnel. Crowd noise increases. They know the opening whistle is about to blow. Then, Mandela sees something in the crowd, at field level.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A GROUP OF ROUGH-LOOKING WHITE MEN WAVE THE NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG AT HIM

direction.raw_text: : A GROUP OF ROUGH-LOOKING WHITE MEN WAVE THE NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG AT HIM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: heads towards this group, towards a wall of his former -- and perhaps current -- enemies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : shit!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . With his bodyguards scrambling to stay in position, Mandela reaches the stands, hand outstretched, leans into the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for honoring our new flag! Some shake his hand, some -- very pointedly -- do not. The crowd noise takes on an ugly undertone -- Mandela is delaying the rugby. Mandela is undeterred. He's into this one-on-one outreach. He turns, looks for more hands to shake -- -- and Jason steps in between Mandela and the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're delaying the rugby, Madiba.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes, of course. Mandela gives one last wave, turns away. As he does, SOMEONE WINDS UP AND THROWS SOMETHING from the stands. Jason and Etienne catch the movement, whirl, too late.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SOMEONE WINDS UP AND THROWS SOMETHING

direction.raw_text: explodes juicily on the field. Mandela didn't see it, doesn't react. If anything, his smile widens as he heads across the field. The bodyguards close around him protectively, get him back to the tunnel.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: AN ORANGE WHIZZES PAST MANDELA'S HEAD,

direction.raw_text: Jason signals for extra bodyguards to escort Mandela all the way up to his box. Hendrick, the biggest, leads the way. Jason stays in the tunnel, along with Etienne. Both men are in a muck sweat, adrenaline coursing through them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you stop him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next time, you try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does he do that sort of thing all the time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ask my ulcer. (BEAT) Good thing that was just an orange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And good thing he never saw it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, he saw it. He sees everything. (rubbing his ulcer) I hate rugby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two international front rows come together with bone- crunching force. Huge, violent men grunt like bulls. The crowd roar vibrates the stadium. The scrum -- a phalanx of eight men locked together against eight -- wheels, buckles, then steadies under the watchful eye of the referee. Fanning out behind each scrum are the backs -- faster, more glamorous players who will run with the ball, or kick it. The Lions scrumhalf thrusts the ball into the maw of the scrum, the huge men lock up against each other with maximum force. The ball comes out the back of the Lions' scrum, the scrumhalf dive-passes it away to the backs, who flick it out laterally to the wing, with lightning speed. The wing lofts a delicate kick just over the onrushing Springbok defenders. The Lions charge the ball, which bounces erratically -- -- right into the hands of the man who kicked it. One last burst of speed, one quick juke to avoid a desperation tackle, and the wing scores in the corner. As the Lions kicker gets ready to convert the try, we find the Springboks huddling under their goal posts, hands on their hips, stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . At the center of the huddle Pienaar bleeds behind his gum guard as, furiously, he tries to inject some fire into his team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Concentrate, dammit! Focus! We can beat these guys if we play our game, not theirs!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he realizes he is not getting through. There is dullness, shock in his player's eyes -- -- which all lift to the heavens as the CONVERSION KICK SOARS through the uprights. We FOLLOW THE KICK as it drops past a GIANT SCOREBOARD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as it registers the conversion and shows the score: LIONS - 10 SPRINGBOKS - 0 INT. LOFTUS VERSFELD STADIUM VIP BOX - DAY In the VIP box, Mandela turns his back on the field as the game restarts beneath him and continues in the background. He has BINOCULARS around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we work while we watch? We have lots of promises to keep. Barbara sits to his right, with her ever-present files and folders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we do. Mary pours tea at the back of the box. Linga stands two steps behind Mandela. On Mandela's left, sits the PRESIDENT OF SOUTH AFRICAN RUGBY, a small man with a small man's ruthlessness and drive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not too late, if the boys can just pick up their game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they don't, heads will roll. This is unacceptable. (LEANING FORWARD) Come on you bloody bastards!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mandela's expression shows that he has a gentleman's distaste for profanity. He turns to Barbara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you want go first, for foreign investment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the money is. America, England, Saudi Arabia. Barbara makes notes. Mandela lifts his BINOCULARS, but instead of looking at the rugby, he looks at the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela zeroes in on an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the apartheid flag. It is being held by the FOUR KHAKI-CLAD BOERS (FARMERS). Classic South African figures from the rural far north, they are already drunk and suicidally depressed by the turn of events on the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you see all the old apartheid flags? It's a disgrace. Mandela lowers his binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's also a constitutional right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Along with the apartheid anthem. I know. But it's time people moved on. Mandela grunts, raises his binoculars again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela finds a SMALL KNOT OF BLACK SPECTATORS, holding the NEW SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG and cheering ecstatically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at that. The whites are cheering for the Springboks, the blacks are cheering for the Lions. Mandela lowers the binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We did that on the island, you know. We supported anyone but the `boks. It really irritated the warders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he thinks about this for a moment, then lifts his binoculars to look at the crowd again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: THROUGH BINOCULARS -- on the knot of black spectators, who leap to their feet, reacting to ACTION ON THE FIELD -- EXT. LOFTUS VERSFELD STADIUM - DAY -- where the Lions score yet another try. This is an ass- whipping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The conversion sails over the `boks heads. The scoreboard clicks over to: LIONS - 20 SPRINGBOKS - O INT. LOFTUS VERSFELD STADIUM VIP BOX - DAY Mandela lowers his binoculars, sets them aside, shakes his head. He knows it's hopeless now. He turns to the Rugby President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long until the World Cup?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plenty of time for improvement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Rugby President can't take it. He stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President -- I wouldn't get my hopes up. We're a damn disgrace. He stomps out of the box, no doubt looking for someone to fire. Mandela gets back to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to go to India and Indonesia, too. There is a knock at the luxury box door. Linga swings to face the door, alert, as a UNIFORMED DOORMAN opens it. The MINISTER OF SPORT (Steve Tshwete), enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry I'm late. He sits down in the empty chair to the right of Mandela.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's it going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very badly. The Minister of Sport checks the score, winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's just as well. Mandela shoots him a sharp look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bending close, talking
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've just been at a meeting of the National Sports Council executive. There's strong support to drop the Springbok emblem and colors altogether. (gesturing at the field) If they're playing badly, maybe its a good time to make a change. (with barely hidden
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) This could be the last time we have to look at the green and gold. The Minister of Sport shoots a glance at Mandela, to see his reaction to all this. Mandela is deep in thought and completely unreadable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One last, bloody, violent bit of play -- then, mercifully, the final whistle blows. Final score: LIONS - 32 SPRINGBOKS - 15. The Lions celebrate. The Springboks head off the field, heads down, shoulders bowed in defeat -- none more bitterly disappointed or bloodier than Francois Pienaar. In the stands, the unheard of happens -- the Springboks are booed by their own fans. Not by everybody, but by enough. We STAY WITH THE `BOKS as they trudge across the field, then clatter along the concrete tunnel to their dressing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The atmosphere is absolutely dismal as the men undress and shower. Nobody catches anybody else's eye. Huge, powerful, pale bodies have been ploughed purple with rake marks, bruises and roasties. Plus, one dark body -- that of CHESTER WILLIAMS, a skilled wing from the Cape, a reserved and private man. Pienaar takes off his green and gold jersey, sits, begins taking off his cleats. His body hurts. He has been raked, scratched, bruised, and his ankle is swollen. A noble warrior, defeated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Francois Pienaar's team came to Loftus Versfeld stadium this afternoon, unprepared and arrogant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meet BOLAND BOTHA as he tapes his commentary on the test match. He is an ex-Springbok player from the boycott years, now turned ponderous, florid rugby commentator. He is a household name, and the last word on the state of the Springboks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They left 80 minutes later with their tails between their legs, like whipped mongrels. (BEAT) And I, for one, am glad. Not because we lost, but because there's now no way to disguise the fact that we are completely and utterly unprepared to reenter the world of top-notch international rugby. Boland defines the South African talent for pessimism and negativity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Rugby World Cup is now less than a year away, and I, for one, am relieved that we are the host nation, and therefore qualify automatically for the tournament. Because I'm not sure we would get in on merit alone. The Rugby President sucks on a rum and coke, watches Boland with one of his HENCHMEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who gets the axe? Someone has to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No after-match party this night. Still depressed by the loss, Pienaar stays home with this fiancee NERINE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pienaar's team played without discipline, without strategy and without courage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's trying to get them to drop me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's just bitter because the Springboks were boycotted when he played.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe, but people listen to what he says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wearing pyjamas, dressing gown and slippers, Mandela multi- tasks, watching Boland Botha and going through a pile of correspondence, scribbling notes or signing his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They brought shame upon our nation, and I, for one, can say without fear of contradiction, that today, these fifteen so-called men did not deserve to wear the hallowed green and gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : a thought, an idea -- a big one -- is churning in his head. He grunts, turns off the TV, puts the correspondence aside, stands. Mary enters with a glass of milk and some pills, on a tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's your muti. I warmed the milk tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're too good to me. Mandela takes his pills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your daughter called, to cancel her visit this weekend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mandela pauses, between pills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did she say why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she didn't. (making it up) She said to tell you she was sorry. Mandela nods, has a hard time swallowing his last pill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you need anything else tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. I'm going to bed. Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Madiba. Sleep well. Mandela smiles at her, but as soon as he is past her, the smile fades. As he climbs the stairs to his bedroom, his face becomes sadder and older and lonelier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela pauses to take off his dressing gown. He looks at his bed. It is as smooth and as blank as a sheet of paper. He peels back the bedclothes at one corner, slides under them and pauses for a moment while reaching for the light switch. He switches off the light and lies down, still and straight. The most popular man in the world starts and ends each day alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very poor township outside Johannesburg. A stark reminder of how much work Mandela has ahead of him. A STAMPEDE OF KIDS runs by. We FOLLOW THE KIDS and find a SMALL, BEAT-UP CHURCH. A noisy
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leads from outside into the church. There is a pecking order in the line, based on size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLEMAN (O.S.) No pushing now! There's enough for everybody!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At a table near the altar, the kids rummage through bags of second-hand clothes under the watchful eye of MRS. COLEMAN, a stout and charitable woman. Next to her, MRS. DLAMINI hands out a lollipop and says -- MRS. DLAMINI God bless you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to each kid. The clothes and lollipops move fast, rhythm kept by Mrs. Dlamini's "God bless yous". The last bag of clothes empties fast as the line of kids reduces until there is only ONE SMALL BOY (SIPHO) left and only one article of clothing. An old SPRINGBOK RUGBY PRACTISE JERSEY. Green and gold. Sipho could use it. His clothes are more holes than anything else. He looks at the Springbok jersey mournfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLEMAN You're a very lucky boy. It's a real Springbok practise jersey! It's a bit big, but it's warm and it'll last for ever! Sipho shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLEMAN It's yours, take it! Go on. Sipho turns and leaves. Mrs. Coleman looks at Mrs. Dlamini, completely confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLEMAN Why won't he take it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DLAMINI If he wears it, the others will beat him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COLEMAN Because the Springboks are playing so badly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DLAMINI No. Because, for them, the Springboks still represent apartheid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eersterust is a settlement and conference location just outside Pretoria. Today it is the location of a full membership meeting of the National Sports Council, an ANC organization that is now the governing body of all sports in South Africa. A banner draped across the conference center entrance tells us so: WELCOME NATIONAL SPORTS COUNCIL.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An NSC FIREBRAND has the podium and the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and now for the next item on our agenda. The hall is jammed. Very few white faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The NSC executive proposes a full membership vote on the following motion ... A ripple of anticipation goes through the delegates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... that as a prominent symbol of the apartheid era, the colors, emblem and name of the Springboks be eliminated immediately ... That causes a stir. The delegates understand how big this is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and that all sports teams representing South Africa shall be known forthwith as the Proteas. Excitement and noise level rises. The NSC Firebrand has to shout through his mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will submit this motion to a hand vote. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) In the event of a close count, we will go to a written ballot. (the moment he's been
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The NSC firebrand shoots his clenched fist into the air. With a roar, the delegates respond, raising their fists. Unanimous. The Springboks are history.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ALL THOSE IN FAVOR OF ELIMINATING THE SPRINGBOKS, RAISE YOUR HANDS

direction.raw_text: , as ONE OF THE OLDER DELEGATES steps outside to make a call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At his desk, Mandela puts down his phone. Anger in his eyes. He slams both palms down hard on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both bodyguard units (minus Jason) are crammed into the small office. The black bodyguards murmur amongst themselves in Xhosa. (Ad-lib.) The white bodyguards talk Afrikaans (ad- lib). No talk between the two units, only tension. Tension broken with a crash as JASON SLAMS THE DOOR OPEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both units to the cars, right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grey BMW, armored grey Mercedes, grey BMW in a line at the entrance. Jason, Kwezi, Winston and Sam scramble out of the building and dive into the lead BMW. Etienne, Hendrick, George and Willem dive into the trailer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brusque, scowling, Mandela marches towards the exit, shadowed by Linga, flanked by Barbara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I tell the Japanese trade delegation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I delegate that decision to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want me to inform the VP?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should at least include the Minister of Sport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Mandela heads out to the cars. Barbara has no choice but to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever the gentleman, Mandela ushers Barbara into the Mercedes. As she gets in:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I strongly advise against doing this. Especially on your own. It ... it gives the impression of autocratic leadership.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela gets in, closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You risk alienating your cabinet and your party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your advice is duly noted, Barbara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madiba ... the people want this. They hate the Springboks. They don't want to be represented by a team they cheered against all their lives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I know. But in this instance the people are wrong. And it is my job as their elected leader to make them see that. Mandela leans forward to talk to Linga.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you tell the boys that Madiba wants to go to Eersterust, very fast. Linga murmurs into his radio. The convoy pulls out, very fast. Barbara makes one last plea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're risking your political capital. You're risking your future as our leader.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The day I am afraid to do that is the day I am no longer fit to lead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least risk it for something more important than rugby. Mandela looks out the window, says nothing, angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela's convoy heads away from Pretoria, very fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... and in concluding this historic conference ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... brothers, sisters, comrades, we in the executive applaud your diligence and courage. The NSC Firebrand and the executive applaud the members. The applause spreads until the hall rocks. They are all very pleased with themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela's convoy roars in. Mandela is the first one out, Linga next. Jason and crew scramble to cover the immediate area. Kwezi opens the door for Barbara on the other side. Mandela strides over to Jason, says something to him. Jason looks surprised, turns to Hendrick. Linga's customary scowl intensifies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the applause finally begins to diminish, the NSC Firebrand turns and nods to a CHURCH CHOIR DIRECTOR, off to the side. The choir director brings his CHOIR onto the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brothers, sisters ... join us in our anthem. Anyone not standing, stands. The choir director raises his hands. The choir inhales. Go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrica etc (God Bless Africa) -- But before the first line is fully sung, an ASSISTANT rushes out, whispers urgently into the NSC Firebrand's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Firebrand's eyes bug out in surprise. He crosses to the Choir Director, says something quickly. The Choir Director stops the choir in mid-chorus. Consternation everywhere. What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brothers, sisters, members of the choir -- we would only interrupt such beautiful music for something truly important. In this case, for someone truly important. (beat, milking it) Please welcome President Mandela! The place goes berserk as Mandela enters, with Linga at his back, and -- surprise, surprise -- Hendrick Booyens leading the way. Face stern and unsmiling, Mandela walks the length of the hall towards the podium. The delegates press in towards them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Jason coordinates security inside and out. Lifts his radio to his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as his standard bad bastard scowl suddenly becomes a smile -- which scares the throng more than the scowl did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Barbara enters at the back of the hall, accompanied by Kwezi. Mandela reaches the podium, turns looks out over the crowd, face thunderous. When they see his anger, the crowd quietens down quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brothers, sisters, comrades, I am here because I feel strongly that you made a decision today without sufficient information or foresight. He lectures them like a headmaster. They don't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am aware of your earlier vote. I am aware that it was unanimous. (BEAT) Nonetheless, I propose that we restore the Springboks. Restore their name, their emblem and their colors, immediately. Instant and complete silence in the hall. This is utterly unpopular. Shocked faces, especially from the executive and the NSC firebrand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she sees her worst political nightmare playing out in front of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me tell you why ... Murmurs of disapproval and disagreement begin to rise. Mandela's going to have to row upstream on this one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... on Robben Island, in Pollsmoor Prison, my jailers were all Afrikaners. (BEAT) For twenty seven years, I studied them. I learned their language, I read their history, I read their poetry. I had to know my enemy, in order to prevail against him. (BEAT) And we prevailed, did we not? All of us here ... we prevailed. For the first time, Mandela says something the crowd likes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our enemy is no longer the Afrikaner. They are our fellow South Africans, our partners in democracy. Just as quickly, Mandela loses them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And they treasure Springbok rugby. If we take that away, we lose them. We prove that we are what they feared we would be. (BEAT) We have to be better than that. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have to surprise them with compassion, with restraint, and generosity. The grumbling and disagreement becomes noticeably louder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I know. All the things they denied us.

direction.raw_text: Room dark but for one small desk light. Pienaar stands at the window, looking out across Cape Town. He is deep in thought. Pienaar turns away from the window, goes to the desk, where, under one small light, we see "Invictus", the poem Mandela wrote out by hand. Pienaar begins reading it. There is a soft knock at his door. Pienaar goes to it, opens it. It is Nerine, accompanied by a cop. Pienaar nods at the cop, steps back so that Nerine can enter. As soon as the door closes behind her, Nerine says:

result.heading: OVER, REFEREE'S WHISTLE BLOWS HARD AND SHARP

direction.raw_text: A massive crowd roars. The Wallaby flyhalf runs forward, puts his boot into the ball, sends it soaring towards the waiting Springboks. The Springbok lock rises high into the air, supported on all sides, takes the ball out of the air perfectly -- -- just as the Wallaby pack closes in and huge men meet with an adrenaline-fueled crunch of bodies. The World Cup has begun at last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not for Chester Williams. Clad in Springbok blazer and tie, he sits behind the coach, the manager and the reserves, in the stands -- and almost succeeds in hiding his utter disappointment at not being on the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela looks on, calmly. The Minister of Sport isn't late for this match. The President of Rugby is pale with nerves. Behind Mandela, stand Linga and Hendrick. The VIP box is a safe place, but Jason isn't taking any chances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jason prowls through the stadium, talking constantly on his radio. Hunter's adrenaline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back to action on the field. The highlights we see here should match the rugby primer we saw in the township. This continues the education of those who do not know rugby. So, for instance, we see a ball knocked forward, and the resulting scrum. We see a ball kicked out of bounds, and the resulting lineout. We see scintillating passing, rucking, mauling, tackling, strategic kicking at it's very best. Both teams are crisp and strong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with SHOTS OF THE SECURITY ARRANGEMENTS (snipers, lots and lots of uniformed cops inside and out, sniffer dogs etc. all overseen by Jason) -- -- with SHOTS OF THE CROWD, which, unlike the earlier test against the Lions, is completely and passionately united behind the Springboks (all commentators talk about the extraordinary passion of the crowd, that day) -- -- always returning to the VIP BOX, where something interesting is taking place right behind Mandela: Linga Moonsamy, the rugby scorner, the soccer lover, loses his scowling reserve and gets sucked into the game.
direction.name: direction

Six times the drive is stopped by Springbok tackling, but the Wallabies keep possession and, on the seventh wave of the assault score a beautiful open try, which is converted. A ripple of concern goes through the crowd -- -- and the VIP box.

The crowd roars. In the VIP box, Mandela is on his feet, shaking hands with everyone he can reach, including Linga and Hendrick, and the waiter. The difficult, angled conversion is missed.

direction.raw_text: By fourteen. Everyone dares to dream. The classic South African penchant for pessimism begins to abate. Two things to note: The crowd roar grows and grows and grows and is echoed in the VIP box. Even Jason turns to look at the action on the field -- but only for a second. Also, this match serves as the coming-out party for the SPRINGBOK FLY HALF, who scores 22 of South Africa's 27 points this day.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed not. My father was a Xhosa chief, and therefore a polygamist. As you know, I am not. (BEAT) But when I look at you ... I envy my father. The man is a major flirt, and really enjoying himself. But, once again, he is dancing with a stranger -- -- and, when we get close to his eyes, we realize that Mandela is pushing himself way past empty.

direction.raw_text: Jason is asleep on his face, in his suit and shoes.

direction.raw_text: Big party, spilling onto the streets. Most of the partiers are white. Black South Africans look on, or serve drinks. We follow the crowd into a big sports bar -- INT. SPORTS BAR - NIGHT -- where the Springboks are pounding beers and blowing off the steam of months of training grind, plus a huge win. Even though most of the players are with their wives or girlfriends, pretty, single women crowd them, two and three deep, men pay for round after round of beers. Pienaar and Nerine are part of the action. Then Pienaar gets a TEXT MESSAGE which makes him shake his head, give Nerine a chagrined look. He grabs the Springbok closest to him, puts his mouth near the player's ear and screams again the hubbub:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .M. SHARP. PASS IT ON. The Springbok shakes his head -- bloody coach -- grabs the player next to him, repeats it. Pienaar watches the message travelling through his team -- and grins. Then, something catches his eye on one of the big overhead TV's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : news footage of the Mandela victory boogie. The boogie is followed by a quick "How far we have come" type of montage. One of the images shows an island ringed by rough surf. Pienaar gets an idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pienaar leads his hung-over, sleep-deprived team on a very slow jog through the mostly empty streets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . When he gets to an intersection, he sneaks a peek down at the palm of his left hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -UP ON PIENAAR'S HAND, where he has drawn a crude street map. Pienaar takes a left at the intersection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another intersection, another peek at the map on his hand, and another left turn, takes the team -- EXT. CAPE TOWN WATERFRONT - DAY -- back onto the waterfront, to an idling FERRY BOAT, where the coach and the manager wait for them -- along with the player's wives and girlfriends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're not that slow next week. Pienaar grins, stops. The team stops around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A change of pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ferry pulls away from the waterfront, with the team on board, pulling on tracksuits against the cold sea air. It is early winter. The seas are fairly rough. So are the stomachs of the `boks who partied hard last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's bloody idea was this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: innocent as a lamb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the ferry, Cape Town and Table Mountain, in all their glory. Ahead of the ferry, one of the most notorious island prisons in modern history -- -- ROBBEN ISLAND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robben Island lies only eight miles from the mainland. It is two miles long, with sandy beaches full of penguins and seals. It would be pretty -- -- but for its MAXIMUM SECURITY PRISON. Concrete, barbed wire, guard towers. (In 1995, the political prisoner wing was shut, but the island still housed criminal prisoners, so the island still had the feel of real incarceration. Today, it is a tourist destination.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they approach the island, a sense of dark history settles over the Springboks and their partners. One of the Springboks turns to a DECKHAND, getting ready to moor at the jetty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do they bring the prisoners here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On this boat. Sobering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Springboks and their partners step onto dry land with some relief, look around at the prison, humbled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Imagine being able to see Cape Town so close by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would make it worse. They head towards the prison entrance, slowly becoming a tighter and tighter bunch. The ghosts of Mandela, and all the others who spent much of their lives here, are very strong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the EXERCISE YARD, the LIME QUARRY, the MESS HALL. None of the usual horsing around. This place affects them, deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Section B is the bleak political wing. Tiny cells line each side of a damp concrete hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shows the Springboks into the hallway, and they dwarf it, as they stand there, shocked. Shocked at what was done in their names. This group is as quiet as we have ever seen them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we see the President's cell?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course. (leading them down past
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've done it up just the way it was. They reach a cell with a piece of white cardboard on the door, showing the number 466/64 -- MANDELA'S PRISON NUMBER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing at the number) That means he was the 466th prisoner admitted in 1964. The Prison Guard unlocks the door, pulls it open, then unlocks the metal grill that is the inside door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pienaar peers into the cell. It is tiny. There is no bed, just a sisal mat on the concrete floor, with a couple of blankets. A chamber pot, a short bench, a tin cup and plate are the only other objects in the room. A couple of small lockers are screwed high to the wall. The barred window is opaque. It lets in light but does not allow the prisoner a view. When Pienaar enters, we see how small the cell really is. He can reach out and touch the opposite walls at the same time. This is a bleak, horrible, dehumanizing place. Pienaar is stunned by it. He turns, slowly, looking at Mandela's world for over twenty years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other Springboks and their partners wait to look into the cell themselves, a little puzzled by how much time Pienaar's taking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pienaar almost looks as if he is in a trance. He hears Mandela's voice in the cell with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (RECITING "INVICTUS") Out of the night that covers me, Black as the pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be For my unconquerable soul. Now, Pienaar sees Mandela in prison clothes, in the cell. (The image is unclear, ghostly.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) In the fell clutch of circumstance I have not winced nor cried aloud. Under the bludgeonings of chance My head is bloody, but unbow'd. Pienaar sees Mandela sitting on the dirt in the prison yard, breaking up rock with a hammer, along with rows of other political prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Beyond this place of wrath and tears Looms but the Horror of the shade, And yet the menace of the years Finds and shall find me unafraid. Pienaar sees Mandela leading his fellow prisoners to the lime quarry, to mine lime under the eye of a guard who looks like Pienaar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) It matters not how strait the gate, How charged with punishment the scroll, I am the master of my fate: I am the captain of my soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gates open. Linga gets out of one BMW, Hendrick out of the other. We know the routine. Only, Mandela doesn't appear for his walk. Linga and Hendrick wait for a moment, then head in through the gate -- EXT. MANDELA'S HOUSE - NIGHT -- break into a sprint, when they see MANDELA'S FORM, CRUMPLED on the lawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara, Mary, the house staff, plus Linga, Hendrick, Etienne and Jason, all wait. All are scared. Nobody talks. The SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS from on the top floor brings them to their feet. MANDELA'S DOCTOR descends the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's simple exhaustion, but it'll lead to worse if it's not treated. He needs complete rest. And I don't mean just shifting the affairs of state to his bedroom. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No phone calls, no visitors, no meetings. No politics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know him. He won't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I'm going to put him into hospital. In isolation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Not yet. I'll threaten him with hospital if he doesn't behave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll cancel everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'll come back tonight to make sure he's not working. The doctor leaves. The rest of them look at each other, relieved ... and maybe a little guilty, for letting things get this bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Mary, aside) Don't cancel the trip to Taiwan. Not yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark. Curtains drawn. The door opens quietly. A shaft of light from the door shows Mandela, on his back in bed, eyes closed. Barbara enters. The sight of Mandela lying like this is chilling. It is too close to what he would look like lying in a casket. Barbara makes sure he is breathing. He is. She unplugs his phone, takes it. Unplugs his TV. Sweeps the room for papers, articles, legal briefs. For the first time, she takes an arm load of stuff away from him. She gives Mandela one last, long look, closes the door behind her. We stay behind and look at Mandela, and ponder South Africa's fate if this were worse than just deep, sedated sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chester Williams jogs under the tense eye of coach, trainer, manager and Pienaar. He accelerates, running fast, but not sprinting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not good enough. Chester opens it up. Full sprint, sustained. Pienaar grins. Chester is back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's hope the Samoans don't injure it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of a typically brutal Samoan tackle, and the ensuing foul play in the maul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S of Chester williams scoring four tries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the Springboks trudging off the field. Every single player is bruised or bleeding, or both.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON THE WORLD CUP BRACKET DIAGRAM

direction.raw_text: Looking frail, but better than before, Mandela pencils in a score ON THE WORLD CUP BRACKET DIAGRAM: SOUTH AFRICA 42, WESTERN SAMOA 14. The diagram shows us that this was a quarter final match. We can see that he has entered all the South African scores. (For the record: South Africa 27 - Australia 18; South Africa
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Romania 3; South Africa 20 - Canada 0.) For the semi-finals, against South Africa, Mandela pencils in France.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . On the other side of the bracket, Mandela pencils in England vs. the All Blacks. With a satisfied grunt, Mandela steps back from the diagram. Things are shaping up nicely. A knock at the door, and Barbara enters, ushering in a GROUP OF LABOR LEADERS.

direction.raw_text: . Jonah Lomu scores in the first two minutes of the match, the first of four tries. He runs through, over, and around hapless defenders. His speed and balance are almost unprecedented in a man his size. The Springboks go quiet as they watch this beating by the All Blacks.

As the `boks rumble past, newspaper vendors, gardeners, pharmacy delivery men on small motorbikes abandon their tasks and run alongside the team. result.heading: CRUNCHING APPROACH OF BIG MEN IN CLEATS

direction.raw_text: `BOKS, we head down the hallway, down some stairs to the tunnel onto the field -- -- where the referee holds his hand up like a traffic cop, keeping the boys in a line in the tunnel. As they wait, they hear the CRUNCHING APPROACH OF BIG MEN IN CLEATS. Down the opposite stairway come THE ALL BLACKS. This is the first time we have seen them in the flesh. Huge men, black on black uniforms, arrogant. Been here before, done this before. The best in the world, expecting nothing but the best from the day. They ignore the Springboks, dismiss them, line up next to them in the tunnel.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: SOUND OF THIRTY MEN JOGGING IN PLACE
result.heading: SOUND OF THIRTY MEN JOGGING IN PLACE

direction.raw_text: . The SOUND OF THIRTY MEN JOGGING IN PLACE in their cleats, on the concrete, sounds like a drum roll before a medieval battle. The Springbok wing sneaks a peek at JONAH LOMU. The biggest, fastest wing ever. Even bigger looking in this confined space. Bigger than the Springbok wing, bigger than any of the Springbok backs, bigger than most of the Springbok forwards. The referee nods to both captains, turns, and leads them onto the field -- EXT. ELLIS PARK STADIUM - DAY -- where the already-whipped up crowd goes crazy, as both teams sprint onto the field and go through their brief warm- up ritual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: focus on how white and old South Africa most of them are. The referee blows his whistle again, and both teams assemble in a line, facing each other. Glaring like boxers across immaculate green grass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seen only in silhouette, Mandela walks down the tunnel. He is flanked by Jason, The Minister of Sport and the President of SA Rugby. Linga, as always, has Mandela's back. Plus Hendrick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mandela emerges into daylight, wearing not a suit, not a Madiba shirt -- -- he is wearing Francois Pienaar's green and gold number 6 rugby jersey. On his head is THE SPRINGBOK CAP given to him by the team in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The crowd catches its breath. This is unprecedented, shocking ... and brilliant. The Springboks digest this extraordinary display of support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (murmuring to Pienaar) The All Blacks won't like that. Pienaar nods, eyes glinting. Mandela is giving them an edge. As he walks towards the waiting teams, Mandela lifts the Springbok cap high, waves it, and fires his famous, beautiful, huge, African smile at the crowd -- -- who roar and stand, slowly, and start chanting, slowly ...

It is abundantly clear why, as the Minister of Sports told Mandela, half of the All Blacks matches are won before the whistle blows. This is very intimidating. Especially because, this day, the All Blacks push the haka closer and closer to the Springboks -- -- who do not back down. In fact, they close ranks and advance. Major, major international smackdown. This is not fake. The emotions, the aggression are real.

direction.raw_text: The referee blows his whistle. The All Black fly half boots the ball towards the Springboks, charges after it, along with the rest of the All Blacks. Game on. We have only seen snippets of rugby, so far. And mostly from a somewhat polite distance -- the usual distance of TV coverage. Say, at closest, the referee's point of view. Not now. Not for the climax. We experience this beautiful piece of mayhem up close and personal. We're inside the heaving scrums. We are the ball. We see the way cleats leave a pattern of round white dimples on abused skin, which quickly turn to purple as they fill with subcutaneous blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We feel a tackle in our own spine; we see teeth sink into flesh in the intimacy of a loose scrum; we feel a hard fist smacking us again and again in the hot privacy of a rolling maul. For this is not a pretty match, not for one moment -- just as the Springbok coach wanted. This match is all about a less talented team stifling the best team in the world by sheer determination and fitness. This is about the Springboks applying continuous, unrelenting pressure, and forcing the vaunted All Black attack into making mistakes. Lots of them. Dropped balls, errant passes, knock-ons. No fluency of movement, no electric building of momentum. Because of one thing: tackling. Tackling and tackling and tackling again. The first time Lomu touches the ball, the stadium, the nation holds its breath -- -- until the Springbok wing scythes into him at thigh height, wraps him up and brings him down. The second time Lomu gets the ball he is brought down from behind by Pienaar, with a picture perfect tackle. We can cut away to the faces of the spectators when we want; from Mandela to Nerine to Sipho and on and on, all over the country. But, in truth, our attention belongs on the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: continually exhorting his men, leading by example, wreaking havoc in the All Black backfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who always seems just one broken tackle away from running one in -- except that there are no broken tackles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who have devoted their entire lives to this moment. They are not playing for money. They are playing for pride, for their countries. Outdated notions. We miss them. No tries are scored in the Final. The two fly halves match each other, penalty goal for penalty goal. With each made kick, the goal posts shrink for the next. The penalty goals are unchallenged. It is up to the kicker to make them or fail. That is pressure.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON THIRTY BIG, STRONG, BATTLE-SCARRED MEN,

direction.raw_text: . The score is 6 - 6 when, just before half time, the Springbok fly half takes a long, perfect pass from the scrum half, and with the All Black defenders looming, kicks a drop goal through the uprights. The Springboks lead 9 - 6. A tight match. So tight, in fact, that there is only one score in the second half -- an All Black drop goal that levels the score at 9 - 9. Until right before the end of the match, when the All Blacks camp in the Springbok half. The scrum half sends a long, spiralling pass to the fly half, who is in perfect position to go for a drop goal. The kick soars into the air, high and straight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: million South Africans hold their breath. All around the world, fans lean forward on their chairs. This will be the decisive blow. But the kick just goes wide. Relief. The referee blows his whistle to signal the end of regulation. Both teams are spent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's the fittest team on this field? The answer lies in their eyes: they are. An All Black penalty goal makes it 12 - 9 almost immediately. A Springbok penalty goal answers. 12 - 12. Seven minutes from the end of extra time, the Springboks earn a scrum deep in All Blacks territory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep it here. Run it forward. The scrum goes down, wheels a little.

direction.raw_text: Francois! Pienaar turns his head. The fly half taps his own chest: give me the ball. Pienaar hesitates, then nods to the scrum half: give him the ball. The ball goes into the scrum. The ball works its way back through the feet of the eight Springbok forwards. The scrum half gathers it, spins it out to the fly half -- -- who takes one step to his left and KICKS A DROP GOAL high into the air. Ball soaring past a backdrop of open mouths. Higher than the uprights ... ... but through them nonetheless. Springboks 15 - 12 All Blacks. An entire nation jumps to its feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is on their feet in the press box.

direction.raw_text: Seven minutes. They turn out to be the longest seven minutes in Mandela's life. In every South African's life.
direction.name: direction

It's over. The Springboks have won.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're waiting for you over there. Pienaar turns, looks. Mandela waits at the podium, eyes alight with joy. In front of him is the WILLIAM WEBB ELLIS TROPHY, a big gold confection. Their eyes meet. Their eyes stay locked as Pienaar fights his way through the press, the officials, his own team, to the podium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mandela holds out his hand. Pienaar takes it. Big hands, one black, one white, one with bruises visible, one with a lifetime of bruises implied. Both wearing the NUMBER 6 SPRINGBOK JERSEY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francois, I want to thank you most sincerely for what you have done to our country. Pienaar shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, I want to thank you for what you have done. Eyes lock again, for just a moment, blue eyes, brown eyes -- African eyes, both. And then PIENAAR RAISES THE TROPHY HIGH. A very traditional sports hero's moment, richly deserved. Real gold, against the green of the battered field. But that is not the real prize. The prize is what happens next, all over the nation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: people spill out into the streets, to celebrate. Utter joy, everywhere, as black and white, servants and employers, strangers, enemies, foreigners are swept up in love and happiness. People who have been suspicious of each other, hated each other, feared each other all their lives ... they hug each other on this day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela undoes the top button of his rugby jersey, settles back with a deep sigh -- -- and drives home through a nation that has begun the process of forgiving itself. His nation.
